The idea began as a partnership between Mrs. Shaw and the [[USO]] in the early 1940s. At this time Mrs. Shaw hosted weekly studio parties in her [[Park Avenue]] gallery in which she asked guest portrait artist to create drawings from life of the [[United States Armed Forces|military]] men and women in attendance. The portraits of men and women in [[Uniforms of the United States Armed Forces|uniform]] were sent as [[Mat (picture framing)|matted]] works of art to the families of the sitters. At the time there were not galleries in New York dedicated to the exhibition of fine portraiture. Mrs. Shaw announced a gallery service for living portrait artists called "The Portrait Painters' Clearing House," then, in 1942, founded Portraits, Inc. {{cite journal |title= Portraits, Inc.: Portrait center of America [ad] |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RHtOAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA369&lpg=PA369&dq=%22Lois+Shaw%22+us+government+portrait&source=bl&ots=-Msa9O3dd8&sig=b7NzAhdw26bqSp4t-FYA7WE2ZKc&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj1hrTCn_PXAhVKQiYKHTitAEwQ6AEIajAU#v=onepage&q=%22Lois%20Shaw%22%20us%20government%20portrait&f=false |journal=Art News Annual |volume=21–24 |page=173.}} Mrs. Shaw was soon joined by [[Helen Appleton Read]],[https://www.aaa.si.edu/collections/helen-appleton-read-papers-9184 “Helen Appleton Read papers, [ca. 1920]-1974"] "[[Smithsonian]] Archives of American Art". Retrieved on December 13, 2017. who became the gallery director and later president of Portraits, Inc.,{{cite news |title=Rare rugs |first=George W. S. |last=Trow |url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/1967/05/13/rare-rugs |newspaper= [[The New Yorker|New Yorker]] |location=New York |date=May 13, 1967 |accessdate=December 13, 2017}} and Andrea Ericson, who served as the [[gallery director]].{{cite book |last=Bell |first=William Gardner |title= Secretaries of War and Secretaries of the Army: Portraits and Biographical Sketches |publisher=Center of Military History, United States Army |date=1981 |location=Washington, D.C. |pages=viii |url=https://history.army.mil/html/books/070/70-12/CMH_Pub_70-12.pdf}} The three are credited for their contributions towards bring [[portraiture]] back in vogue in the United States. ===Birmingham and Flat Rock=== [[File:Portraits Inc Birmingham gallery and corporate office.jpg|thumb|default|Portraits, Inc. Birmingham gallery]] In 2008, Portraits, Inc., was purchased by Beverly B. McNeil{{ cite news |title=Every picture tells a story |url=http://bhmbiz.com/2017/09/29/every-picture-tells-a-story/ |newspaper=Bhm Biz |location=Birmingham |date=September 29, 2017 |accessdate=December 13, 2017}} and Julia G. Baughman.{{cite news |first=Rachel |last=Hellwig |title=Sharing her passion |url=http://ironcity.ink/happenings/sharing-her-passion1027/ |newspaper=Iron City Ink |location=Birmingham |date=October 27, 2016 |accessdate=December 13, 2017}} McNeil, owner of Portrait Brokers of America in [[Birmingham, AL]], merged the two companies. Two years later, owner Ruth Reeves joined in partnership when she brought a third agency, The Portrait Source from [[Flat Rock, Henderson County, North Carolina|Flat Rock, NC]], under the Portraits, Inc. name.{{ cite news |first=Joey |last=Millwood |title=Right artist key to portraits|url=http://www.blueridgenow.com/news/20130211/right-artists-key-to-portraits |newspaper=Hendersonville [[Times-News (Hendersonville, North Carolina)|Times-News]] |location=Hendersonville |date=February 11, 2013 |accessdate=December 6, 2017}} ==Artists== Portraits, Inc. has established relationships with artists and advocated for the field of [[portrait painting]] for over 75 years. The roster of artists has included [[Andrew Wyeth]],[http://www.tfaoi.com/aa/5aa/5aa199.htm “Salmagundi Club: An American Institution”] "Dubuque Museum of Art: Traditional Fine Arts Organizations, Inc.”, March 20, 2005. Retrieved on December 7, 2017. Henrietta Wyeth,{{citation |first=Jean |last=Fitzgerald |title= A Finding Aid to the Peter Hurd and Henriette Wyeth Hurd Papers, 1917–1993 |url=https://www.aaa.si.edu/files/resources/finding-aids/pdf/hurdpete.pdf |publisher=[[Smithsonian]] Archives of American Art |place=Washington, D.C. |year=1996 |pages=2–11}} [[Albert Murray (artist)|Albert Murray]], [[Robert Brackman]], [[John Koch]], Samuel Edmund Oppenheim, [[Sidney Dickinson]], [[Aaron Shikler]], [[Marshall Bouldin III|Marshall Bouldin, III,]]{{cite book |last=Donley|first=Richard|title= Everything Has Its Price: The Indispensable Price Guide for Anyone Who Ever Wondered, How Much Does that Cost? |date=March 10, 1995|page=86}} and [[Nelson Shanks]]. Today the agency represents more than 100 [[portrait artists]] across the U.S. and internationally. Notable artists include [[Daniel Greene (artist)|Daniel E. Greene]],{{cite book |last1=Green |first1=Daniel E., |last2=Bloomfield |first2=Maureen |title= Daniel E. Greene Studios and Subways: An American Master His Life and Art |date=December 10, 2017 |page=207}} [[Everett Raymond Kinstler]], [[John Howard Sanden]],[http://www.johnhowardsanden.com/newsroom-news&events.asp “The white house portraits & selected recent portrait”] "[[John Howard Sanden]]". Retrieved December 5, 2017 Burton Silverman, [[Michael Shane Neal]],[http://michaelshaneneal.com/publications/portrait-painting-the-first-ten-years/ “Portrait painting, The first ten years”] "[[Michael Shane Neal]]". Retrieved December 5, 2017. and Sharon Sprung.{{cite news |title= Sharon Spring's latest commission |url=http://www.asllinea.org/sharon-sprungs-latest-commission/ |newspaper=Linea |publisher= Art Students League of New York |date=October 11, 2016 |accessdate=December 13, 2017}} Five portrait artists exclusively represented by Portraits, Inc., are David Goatley, Carol Baxter Kirby, Liz Lindstrom,{{cite news |first=Daniel |last=Maidman |title=Dispatch from the figurative arts |url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/daniel-maidman/dispatch-from-the-figurat_b_7558142.html |newspaper=Huffington Post |date=June 10, 2016 |accessdate=December 12, 2017}} [[Michele Rushworth]], and Jennifer R. Welty. ==Scholarship foundation== The Portraits, Inc. Scholarship Program was established in 2001 to provide annual funding to children and grandchildren of agency [[portrait artists]]. University scholarships are awarded each year to qualifying applicants. Six scholarship named in honor of the artist and staff Lifetime Achievement Award Winners.{{cite news |first=Lauren |last=Helmer |title=Kelly Moffatt: FACES of Birmingham |url=https://styleblueprint.com/birmingham/everyday/kelly-moffatt-faces-birmingham/ |newspaper=Style Blue Print |location=Nashville |accessdate=December 13, 2017}} ==References== ==External links== * [https://portraitsinc.com/ Portraits, Inc.] [[Category:1942 establishments in New York (state)]] [[Category:American companies established in 1942]] [[Category:Business of visual arts]] [[Category:Companies based in Birmingham, Alabama]]

{{Infobox artwork | title = Praetorians Relief | image_file = Lens - Inauguration du Louvre-Lens le 4 décembre 2012, la Galerie du Temps, n° 058.JPG | image_size = 300px | other_language_1 = French | other_title_1 = | type = [[Relief#High relief|High relief]], [[bas-relief]] | artist = unknown | year = {{circa|51–52}} | material = Grey veined [[marble]] | height_metric = 160 | width_metric = 122 | height_imperial = | width_imperial = | condition = Extant | accession = LL.398 | city = | museum = [[Louvre-Lens]], France | coordinates = | url = }}
The '''Praetorians Relief''' is a [[Ancient Rome|Roman]] marble relief dated to {{circa|51–52}} AD and housed in the [[Louvre-Lens]].<ref name="afa">{{cite web | url =http://www.afaweb.org/exhibitions/details/documents/HighlightsofRomanArtfromtheLouvre.pdf| title =Highlights of Roman art from the Louvre|publisher =[[American Federation of Arts]]| page=3|accessdate =23 Aug 2014}}</ref>
It depicts three soldiers in [[Relief#High relief|high relief]] in the foreground, while two others in the background, accompanied by a standard bearer, are made in [[bas-relief]]. The standard-bearer holds an [[Aquila (Roman)|aquila standard]], where the eagle grasps a thunderbolt in its talons. The soldiers have been identified as [[Praetorians]] due to the richness of the apparel, particularly the helmets, the ceremonial dress and oval shields.<ref>{{cite book | author =Lawrence Keppie | title =The Making of the Roman Army: From Republic to Empire| publisher =University of Oklahoma Press | year =1998 | pages =233–234 | isbn =0806130148}}</ref> The figures are wearing [[calcei]] and not [[caligae]], worn by ordinary soldiers. However, according to [[Boris Rankov]], "the [[Attic helmet|Attic-style helmets]] are almost certainly an artistic convention".<ref name="Rankov">{{cite book | author =Boris Rankov | title =The Praetorian Guard| publisher =Osprey Publishing | year =1994 | page =20 | isbn =1855323613}}</ref> Rankov suggests that "early in their history the Praetorians were still using the [[Montefortino helmet|Montefortino-style helmet]] normal in the [[Roman legion|legions]] of the [[Roman Republic|Republic]] and early [[Roman Empire|Empire]]".<ref name="Rankov"/>
The relief was previously dated to the early 2nd century AD. The lower half of the left-hand figure, portions of the middle two and the heads of all three foreground figures are modern restorations. In 2006 the relief underwent restoration by N. Imbert and A. Méthivier.<ref name="Ancientrome">{{cite web | url =http://ancientrome.ru/art/artwork/img.htm?id=2537| script-title=ru:Рельеф с преторианцами |publisher =Ancientrome.ru| language=Russian|accessdate =23 Aug 2014}}</ref>
==Provenance== The Praetorians Relief was once part of the [[Arch of Claudius (British victory)|Arch of Claudius]], erected in 51 to commemorate the [[Roman conquest of Britain|conquest of Britain]].<ref name="afa"/> The relief is mentioned already in the 16th century. The head of the standard-bearer is depicted in ''Album'' by [[Pierre Jacques de Reims]], on the page dated to 1577.<ref name="Ancientrome"/> The relief was once in the possession of the [[Mattei family]], in 1824 it was purchased by the French.

[[File:Philadelphia Museum of Art Pennsylvania USA.jpg|right|thumb|300px|The front entrance and steps to the Philadelphia Museum of Art]] [[File:Sylvester Stallone, Tessa Thompson, and Michael B. Jordan promoting Creed at the Philadelphia Art Museum.JPG|thumb|right|300px|[[Sylvester Stallone]], [[Tessa Thompson]], and [[Michael B. Jordan]] promoting ''[[Creed (film)|Creed]]'' atop the Rocky Steps in November 2015.]] The 72 stone steps before the entrance of the [[Philadelphia Museum of Art]], in [[Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]], have become known as the "'''Rocky Steps'''" as a result of the scene from the film ''[[Rocky (film)|Rocky]]''. Tourists often mimic Rocky's famous climb, a metaphor for an underdog or an everyman rising to a challenge.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.visitphilly.com/museums-attractions/philadelphia/the-rocky-statue-and-the-rocky-steps/ | title=The Rocky Statue and the Rocky Steps | publisher=Visit Philadelphia | work=VisitPhilly.com | accessdate=March 3, 2014}}</ref> A bronze '''''Rocky'' statue''' was briefly situated at the top of the steps for the filming of ''[[Rocky III]]''. This statue, now located at the bottom right of the steps, is a popular photo opportunity for visitors. The top of the steps offers a commanding view of [[Eakins Oval]], the [[Benjamin Franklin Parkway]], and [[Philadelphia City Hall]].
In 2006, Rocky creator [[Sylvester Stallone]] recounted the genesis of the iconic scene: (while filming the 1976 movie) the film crew, bound by a tight budget, identified the steps one night while searching for filming locations around the city. Stallone first thought Rocky should carry his dog Butkus up the steps, but the big [[bull mastiff]] proved too heavy for the scene to work. Still, the view from the top of the stairs inspired him to reshoot the scene without the dog. Also in ''[[Rocky Balboa (film)|Rocky Balboa]]'', Rocky lifts his dog Punchy when he reaches the top of the steps. The [[closing credits]] of ''Rocky Balboa'' show a montage of dozens of people running up the steps.
This scene was one of the first uses in a major film of the [[Steadicam]], a stabilized camera mount that allows its operator to walk and even climb steps while smoothly filming.<ref name="steadicam30anniv">{{cite press release | url=http://lserv2.dtopinc.com/tiffen/staging_html/tiffen_news_Steadicam30th_Anniv.html | title=Steadicam Celebrates its 30th Anniversary at NAB 2005 | publisher=Tiffen | date=April 2005 | accessdate=March 3, 2014 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140430033456/http://lserv2.dtopinc.com/tiffen/staging_html/tiffen_news_Steadicam30th_Anniv.html | archivedate=April 30, 2014 | df= }}</ref>
==Bronze ''Rocky'' statue== [[File:Philly042107-014-RockyStatue.jpg|thumb|left|The ''Rocky'' statue, situated just northeast of the steps]] [[File:Philadelphia skyline-daytime.JPG|thumb|right|View of the Ben Franklin Parkway from the top of the steps]] Before ''Rocky III'', released in 1982, Stallone commissioned [[A. Thomas Schomberg]] to create a bronze statue of Rocky.<ref name="pophistorydig">{{cite web | url=http://www.pophistorydig.com/?tag=rocky-statue-philadelphia-art-museum | title=The Rocky Statue | work=The Pop History Dig | date=2009-07-20 | author=Doyle, Jack}}</ref> Three 2-ton, 10-foot-tall copies were to be cast. One was installed atop the steps for the filming of ''Rocky III'', and was ultimately relocated at the bottom of the steps. The second ''Rocky'' is in the [[San Diego Hall of Champions|San Diego Hall of Champions Sports Museum]] in [[San Diego, California]]. The third was planned, but was not cast at the time.
A third casting of the statue was put up for auction to raise funds for charities. The third was listed on [[eBay]] three separate times between 2002-2005, with a starting bid of US$5,000,000, then US$3,000,000, and finally US$1,000,000 to raise funds for the International Institute for Sport and Olympic History. In 2006, Schomberg studios realized the casting mold for the statue was beginning to decay, and had a third and final edition of the statue cast in bronze. The third statue is currently exhibited at the Schomberg's gallery in Colorado <ref name="pophistorydig" /><ref>{{cite press release | url=http://www.harveyabramsbooks.com/501c3press1.html | title=Yo! Rocky can be yours! | publisher=International Institute for Sport and Olympic History | date=2003-05-16 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050728092933/http://www.harveyabramsbooks.com/501c3press1.html | archivedate=2005-07-28 | df= }}</ref>
After filming was complete, a debate arose between the Art Museum and Philadelphia's Art Commission over the meaning of "[[art]]". City officials, who argued that the ''Rocky'' statue was not "art" but a "movie [[Theatrical property|prop]]", eventually moved it to the front of the [[Philadelphia Spectrum]].<ref>{{cite news |last= Rose|first= Joel|date= July 30, 2006|title= ‘Prop’ Culture? Rocky Statue Blurs Art Line|url= https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=5593082|newspaper= WHYY National Public Radio, All Things Considered|location= Philadelphia, PA |access-date=December 16, 2016 }}</ref>
It was later returned to the Art Museum for the filming of ''[[Rocky V]]'', then brought back to the Spectrum. The statue was replaced with a bronze inlay of Converse sneaker footprints with the name "Rocky" above them.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.pophistorydig.com/topics/the-rocky-statue-1980-2009/|title= The Rocky Statue: 1980-2009|last= Doyle|first= Jack |date= July 20, 2009|website= pophistorydig.com|publisher= |access-date= December 16, 2016|quote=}}</ref>
On September 8, 2006, the ''Rocky'' statue was returned to the Art Museum and placed on a pedestal in a grassy area near the foot of the steps to the right of the Museum. The unveiling ceremony included live music, the debut of the first full trailer for ''Rocky Balboa,'' and a free showing of the first ''Rocky'' movie. At the ceremony, Philadelphia Mayor [[John F. Street|John Street]] said that the steps were one of Philly's biggest tourist attractions, and that Stallone, a native [[New York City|New Yorker]], had become "the city's favorite adopted son".<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/09/08/AR2006090801620_pf.html | title=Rocky Is Back Where He Belongs | work=The Washington Post | date=2006-09-08 | agency=The Associated Press | accessdate=March 3, 2014 | author=Gelston, Dan}}</ref>
==In popular culture== [[File:Rocky poster (British).jpg|British Theatrical Movie Poster|200px|right]] The ''Rocky'' film scene has become a cultural icon. Many tourists visit the steps to recreate the scene themselves.<ref name="straziuso20040701">{{cite news | url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2004/07/01/entertainment/main627057.shtml | title=Nostalgic Jaunt To 'Rocky' Steps | work=CBS News | date=2004-07-01 | agency=Associated Press | accessdate=March 24, 2013 | author=Straziuso, Jason}}</ref> [[E!|E! Channel]] ranked it No. 13 in its ''101 Most Awesome Moments in Entertainment''.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.eonline.com/On/101/MostAwesome/List/index5.html | title=E! Channel's 101 Most Awesome Moments in Entertainment | publisher=E! Entertainment Television, Inc. | work=E! Online | accessdate=29 May 2012 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041205205959/http://www.eonline.com/On/101/MostAwesome/List/index5.html | archivedate=2004-12-05}}</ref> During the [[1996 Olympic Torch Relay]], Philadelphia native [[Dawn Staley]] was chosen to run up the museum steps. The steps are the backdrop for the annual Independence Day celebration, and have often been featured in large concerts such as [[Live 8]]. Two journalists from the ''[[Philadelphia Inquirer]]'' spent a year interviewing people who ran the steps, and published a book in 1996 called ''Rocky Stories: Tales of Love, Hope, and Happiness at America's Most Famous Steps''.<ref>{{cite book | last = Vitez | first = Michael | title = Rocky stories : tales of love, hope, and happiness at America's most famous steps | publisher = Paul Dry Books | location = Philadelphia, Pa | year = 2006 | isbn = 1589880293}}</ref> The [[2017 NFL Draft]] was held from the steps, the first time the NFL draft was held outdoors.<ref>{{cite web|title=Parkway, and perhaps Rocky steps, to be stage for 2017 NFL draft|url=http://www.philly.com/philly/news/20160902_Parkway_and_perhaps_Rocky_Steps_to_be_stage_for_2017_NFL_Draft.html|publisher=philly.com|date=September 2, 2016|accessdate=March 9, 2017}}</ref>
The scene has inspired homages and parodies since Rocky was released in 1976. * In ''[[The Simpsons]]'' episode "[[I'm Spelling as Fast as I Can]]", [[Lisa Simpson]] runs up a flight of stairs wearing a tracksuit similar to Rocky's.<ref>{{cite web|accessdate = 25 September 2006|url = http://www.tv.com/the-simpsons/im-spelling-as-fast-as-i-can/episode/181997/trivia.html|title = I'm Spelling as Fast as I Can @ TV.com}}</ref> * In the film ''[[In Her Shoes (2005 film)|In Her Shoes]]'', [[Toni Collette]]'s character, Rose Feller, runs up the steps with four dogs. * On an episode of ''[[The Fresh Prince of Bel Air]]'', the character Will, while back in Philly, trains for a big fight against a former childhood bully; the training ends with Will running up the steps to "[[Gonna Fly Now]]", and celebrating and passing out, where a passer-by steals his wallet and hat. * In the [[Eddie Murphy]] movie ''[[The Nutty Professor (1996 film)|The Nutty Professor]]'', [[Sherman Klump]] runs up the steps to one of his college's buildings, parodying the scene. * Participants in Philadelphia's monthly [[Critical Mass (cycling)|Critical Mass]] bike ride generally finish up by cycling to the Rocky Steps, hoisting their bicycles, running up the steps, then lifting their bikes above their heads. * In a [[Reebok]] campaign, [[Allen Iverson]], then with the [[Philadelphia 76ers]], ran up the steps while dribbling a basketball. * In the ''[[Boy Meets World]]'' episode, "The Witches of Pennbrook" Eric says that he and Jack are going to run up the steps and had been planning it for months. * In the opening episode of the 2005 boxing reality television series ''[[The Contender (TV series)|The Contender]]'' (which featured and was executive produced by Stallone), Philadelphia native [[Najai Turpin]] ran up the steps.

'''Sandra Alland''' is a [[Glasgow]]-based [[Scottish-Canadian]] writer, interdisciplinary artist, [[small press]] publisher, performer,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.xtra.ca/public/Toronto/Zorras_embarks_on_Canadian_tour-10847.aspx|title=Zorras embarks on Canadian tour|last=LaRiviere|first=Serafin|date=October 1, 2011|work=Xtra|accessdate= July 10, 2012}}</ref> filmmaker and curator. Alland's work focuses on social justice, language, humour and experimental forms.
==Life and work== Sandra Alland grew up in [[Scarborough, Toronto|Scarborough]], a suburb of [[Toronto|Toronto, Ontario]], Canada. She was raised by a Scottish migrant father and grandfather, and a mother of French-Canadian and Dutch descent. The first in her family to attend university, Alland completed undergraduate studies in Drama at the [[University of Toronto]], graduating with high distinction in 2000.
Alland began publishing and performing her work in Toronto in 1995. From 1995 to 1997, she was part of the [[performance poetry]] band Stumblin' Tongues, with Bermudian poet [[Andra Simons]] and musicians Garth and Grant Kien. Alland worked extensively in Toronto's theatre, literary and visual art communities until she relocated to Scotland in 2007.
Alland has published two collections of poetry: ''Proof of a Tongue'' (McGilligan Books, 2004) and ''Blissful Times'' (BookThug, 2007). In 2009, Edinburgh's Forest Publications published a chapbook of her short stories, ''Here's to Wang.'' Her poetry chapbook ''Naturally Speaking,'' a meditation on disability poetics and gender, was published in 2012 by Toronto's espresso<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.xtra.ca/public/National/Fresh_start-12877.aspx|title=Fresh Start|last=Dupuis|first=Chris|date=November 30, 2012|work=Xtra}}</ref> and was joint winner of the 2013 [[bpNichol]] Chapbook Award.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://meetthepresses.wordpress.com/2013/11/18/2013-bpnichol-chapbook-award-winners-announced/|title=2013 bpNichol Chapbook Award Winners Announced!|last=Award|first=bpNichol|date=November 18, 2013|work=Meet the Presses}}</ref>
In a four-star performance review in December 2007, Edinburgh's ''[[The Skinny (magazine)|The Skinny]]'' said: "(In) Sandra Alland's brilliant [[Samuel Beckett|Beckett]] cut-ups...the images come so fast you sometimes feel like a Slinky falling down the stairs, yet the emotion and intention are clear, moving, and often funny."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theskinny.co.uk/latest/40973-whos_your_dandy_word_power_books_edinburgh_12_nov|title=Who's Your Dandy|last=MacDonald|first=Hamish|date=December 7, 2007|work=The Skinny}}</ref> In spring 2009, Glasgow's ''Lock Up Your Daughters'' magazine said: "Reminiscent of [[Miranda July]] and complemented by a deadpan delivery, Alland's words are at once both drolly funny and sweetly strange."
In 2017 co-edited ''Stairs and Whispers: D/deaf and Disabled Poets Write Back'' (Nine Arches Press).<ref>[http://ninearchespress.com/publications/poetry-collections/stairs%20and%20whispers.html "Stairs and Whispers: D/deaf and Disabled Poets Write Back"], Nine Arches Press.</ref> Alland's writing has been published internationally in anthologies including ''Protest: Stories of Resistance''<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://glasgowreviewofbooks.com/2017/11/15/some-thoughts-on-protest/|title=SOME THOUGHTS ON ‘PROTEST’|last=Bell|first=Henry|date=November 15, 2017|work=Glasgow Review of Books|access-date=June 14, 2018|language=en-US}}</ref> ([[Comma Press]]), ''Thought X: Fictions and Hypotheticals'' (Comma Press), ''The Mirror in the Mirror'' (Comma Press), ''The State of the Arts: Living with Culture in Toronto'' ([[Coach House Books]]), ''radiant danse uv being: A Poetic Portrait of [[bill bissett]]'' (blewointment), ''Red Light: Superheroes, Saints, and Sluts'' ([[Arsenal Pulp Press]]), ''My Lump in the Bed: Love Poems for George W. Bush'' (Dwarf Puppets on Parade), ''Can't Lit: Fearless Fiction from Broken Pencil Magazine'', and ''Poems For [[Pussy Riot]]'' ([[PEN International]]). Alland's poems and short stories can be found in such publications as ''[[This Magazine]]'', ''[[Broken Pencil]]'', dig, Cosmonauts Avenue, subTerrain and ''[[Gutter magazine|Gutter]]''. In 2012, Alland edited a feature on Scottish poetry for ''[[Jacket2]]''.
Besides text, Alland works in [[multimedia]], film, performance poetry and [[sound poetry]]. She currently collaborates with the Scottish interdisciplinary group They They Theys, who received 5 stars from Scotland's ''The Skinny'' in March 2014.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theskinny.co.uk/theatre/reviews/307342-seep_fluidity_in_body_landscape_media_education|title=SEEP: Fluidity in Body & Landscape @ Media Education|last=Karoulla|first=Eric|date=March 7, 2014|work=The Skinny}}</ref> From 2007 to 2012 Alland collaborated with the poetry-music-video fusion group [[Zorras]]. In autumn 2009, Scotland's ultimatemetal.com said of her work: "A very unique mix of poetry, music, stories and just plain weird. The poetry was sharp and funny, the placement effective, the visuals fitting; a rather unforgettable experience."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ultimatemetal.com/forum/live-reviews/531551-cocoon-counter-culture-festival-edinburgh-scotland-12-13-september-2009-a.html|title=Cocoon Counter Culture Festival|last=Brand|first=Simon|date=September 30, 2009|work=Ultimate Metal}}</ref> Alland is featured in [[Andrea Brady]]'s Archive of the Now ([[Queen Mary University of London|Queen Mary]])<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.archiveofthenow.org/authors/?i=182|title=Archive of the Now|last=Brady|first=Andrea|date=October 2013|website=www.archiveofthenow.org|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=June 14, 2018}}</ref>.
In the UK, Alland has performed at such places as [[Roundhouse (venue)|The Roundhouse]], [[Barbican Centre]], [[Edinburgh International Book Festival]], [[Museum of London]], [[Soho Theatre]], [[The Oxford Playhouse]], [[Queer Mutiny]], [[Aye Write!]], [[The Arches (Glasgow)|The Arches]], [[The Forest (social centre)|The Forest]] and [[Unity Theatre, Liverpool]]. In Canada, she has featured at series including Impossible Words, AvantGarden, Mayworks Festival of Working People and the Arts, Contact Photography Festival, the Ottawa International Writers' Festival, LabCab Festival ([[Factory Theatre]]) and [[Hillside Festival]].
Alland's visual art and videos were on display at Glasgow's [[Gallery of Modern Art, Glasgow|Gallery of Modern Art]] and [[mac (Birmingham)]], during 2009–10 and 2011 respectively. Along with [[Ajamu X]], Alland was the inaugural artisit-in-residence at Glasgow's Trongate 103 in 2009.
Alland's films have screened internationally, including at [[Tate Modern]], [[Macrobert]], Entzaubert Festival (Berlin), [[International Festival Entr'2 marches|Entr'2 Marches]] and [[MIX Copenhagen]]. In 2013, she was awarded a Cultural Commissions grant from [[Creative Scotland]] and [[LGBT History Month]] Scotland, to begin work on new documentary shorts, and to mentor six new LGBTQ disabled and Deaf filmmakers.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.list.co.uk/article/48167-lgbt-history-month-2013-programme-highlights/|title=LGBT History Month 2013 - programme highlights|last=Mayberry|first=Lauren|date=January 23, 2013|work=The List}}</ref> In 2016–17, Alland was commissioned by Disability Arts Online and SICK! Festival to curate a playlist of films about D/deaf and disabled artists, and co-create five new short documentaries.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.disabilityartsonline.org.uk/DAO-commission-SICK-festival-announcement|title=News: Disability Arts Online commissions new video works in partnership with SICK! Festival - disability arts online|last=Editor|first=|date=November 15, 2015|website=www.disabilityartsonline.org.uk|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=June 14, 2018}}</ref>.
Alland has curated projects and events for entities including [[Edinburgh Filmhouse]], Disability Arts Online, Artscape's Queen West Art Crawl, [[This Ain't the Rosedale Library]], [[Toronto Women's Bookstore]], and [[The Theatre Centre]]. She founded and curates Edinburgh's Cachín Cachán Cachunga! and SEEP, a multimedia performance and visual arts project featuring queer, trans and intersex artists.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.list.co.uk/article/26863-cachin-cachan-cachunga/|title=Cachín Cachán Cachunga!|last=Innes|first=Kirsten|date=July 7, 2010|work=The List}}</ref> In 2018, Alland curated the first widely-accessible short film programme featuring queer and trans D/deaf and disabled artists at [[BFI Flare: London LGBT Film Festival|BFI Flare]], called ''Fighters of Demons, Makers of Cakes''.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.bfi.org.uk/news-opinion/news-bfi/announcements/bfi-flare-2018-full-programme-revealed|title=BFI Flare 2018 full programme revealed|last=|first=|date=February 21, 2018|work=British Film Institute|access-date=June 14, 2018|language=en}}</ref>.
Alland is [[queer]], disabled, genderqueer and working poor.<ref>[http://www.tyci.org.uk/wordpress/lgbt-history-month-sandra-alland/ "LGBT History Month – Sandra Alland"]. ''TYCI'', February 5, 2013.</ref>
==Works== '''Books''' *2000: ''The Mathematics of Love''. Toronto: 13th Tiger Press *2004: ''Proof of a Tongue''. Toronto: McGilligan *2007: ''Blissful Times''. Toronto: BookThug *2009: ''Here's to Wang''. Edinburgh: Forest Publications *2012: ''Naturally Speaking''. Toronto: espresso *2017: ''Stairs and Whispers: D/deaf and Disabled Poets Write Back''. Rugby: Nine Arches Press. Eds Alland, Barokka, Sluman.

[[Image:STdlO apse.jpg|thumb|300px|right|Horseshoe arches in the principal chapel (apse).]]
The '''Santo Tomás de las Ollas''' hermitage is situated in the town with the same name close to [[Ponferrada]], [[León, Spain|León]] ([[Spain]]).
==History== [[Image:STdlO interior.jpg|thumb|300px|right|Double horseshoe arch which separates the principal chapel from the nave.]]
The name of the hermitage, taken from the town Santo Tomás de las Ollas (St. Thomas of the [[Ollas]]), comes from the main occupation of that locality: pottery. They supplied to the [[Valle del Silencio]] zone.
The hermitage was donated to the community of [[San Pedro de Montes]] monastery by the [[Bishop of Astorga]].

Pozdneev]] | year=1959 | type=[[Oil painting|Oil on board]] | height_metric=130 | width_metric=94 | height_imperial=52 | width_imperial=37 | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | city= [[Saint Petersburg]] | museum=[[private collection]] }}
'''''Spring Day''''' (Russian: [http://cyclowiki.org/wiki/%D0%92%D0%B5%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D0%B4%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%8C_(%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%9D._%D0%9F%D0%BE%D0%B7%D0%B4%D0%BD%D0%B5%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%B0) ''Весенний день (картина Н. Позднеева)''] is a painting by the well-known Russian artist [[Nikolai Pozdneev|Nikolai Matveevich Pozdneev]]<ref>''Directory of Members of the Union of Artists of USSR. Volume 2.''- Moscow: Soviet artist, 1979. P. 216.</ref> (1930–1978). It attempts to convey the mood of Soviet society of the late 1950s to the early 1960s.
==History== ''Spring Day'' was one of the first original genre compositions by Nikolai Pozdneev. He developed the theme for the first time raised three years earlier in his graduate painting ''From the School'' (1956, now reside in collection of the Pskov Painting Gallery). The first version of painting shown in 1960 on the principal Art Show in Leningrad<ref>''Exhibition of works by Leningrad artists of 1960. Exhibition catalogue.'' - Leningrad: Khudozhnik RSFSR, 1961. P. 33.</ref> and in Moscow<ref>''The Soviet Russia. The Republic Exhibition of 1960. Exhibition catalogue.'' - Moscow: Soviet Artist, 1960. P. 65.</ref> the author does not fully satisfied. Pozdneev repainted the picture, making it a more extended vertically. A group of children has shifted from the center to the upper left corner. The bold decision proved justified: composition of the painting acquired aspiration, which is consistent with the general concept of the work. Were reinforced color accents, the lighter has become the whole palette of the picture. As a result, in the work began to fully feel the air of spring and hope, in tune with the mood of the era turn of the decades.
From 1960 to 1980, ''Spring Day'' was kept in the artist's family. In 1994, after a long pause, it was featured at the [[Leningrad painting of 1950-1980s (Saint Petersburg, 1994)|''Painting of 1940-1990s. The Leningrad School'']] Art Show in the Exhibition Halls of the [[Saint Petersburg Union of Artists]].<ref>''Paintings of 1950-1980s by the Leningrad School's artists. Exhibition catalogue.'' Saint Petersburg, Saint Petersburg Union of Artists, 1994. P.4.</ref>
In 1995-1996 ''Spring Day'' was exhibited in Saint Petersburg in the ''Nekrasov Memorial Museum'' at the exhibitions [[Lyrical motifs in postwar Leningrad painting (Saint Petersburg, 1995)|''The Lyrical motive in painting of artists of the WWII generation'']],<ref>[[Lyrical motifs in postwar Leningrad painting (Saint Petersburg, 1995)|''Lyrical motives in the works of artists of the WWII generation. Painting, drawings. Exhibition catalogue.'']] Saint Petersburg, Nikolai Nekrasov Memorial museum, 1995. P.6.</ref> and [[Painting of 1940-1990s. The Leningrad School (Saint Petersburg, 1996)|''Painting of 1940-1990s. The Leningrad School'']].<ref>[[Painting of 1940-1990s. The Leningrad School (Saint Petersburg, 1996)|''Painting of 1940-1990s. The Leningrad School. Exhibition catalogue'']]. Saint Petersburg, Nikolai Nekrasov Memorial museum, 1996. P.6.</ref>
The painting was reproduced on the official poster and cover of exhibition catalog.
In 2007 the ''Spring Day'' was reproduced and described among 350 art works by Leningrad artists in the book «''Unknown Socialist Realism. The Leningrad School''»,<ref>[http://cyclowiki.org/wiki/%D0%9D%D0%B5%D0%B8%D0%B7%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9_%D1%81%D0%BE%D1%86%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%B7%D0%BC._%D0%9B%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B3%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B4%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D1%88%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B0 Sergei V. Ivanov. Unknown Socialist Realism. The Leningrad School. Saint Petersburg, NP-Print Edition, 2007.] P.201.</ref> published in Russian and English.

[[Image:Standrewssarcophagus.jpg|300px|thumb|right|The St Andrews Sarcophagus.]]
The '''Saint Andrews Sarcophagus''' is a [[Picts|Pictish]] monument dating from the second half of the 8th century. The [[sarcophagus]] was recovered beginning in 1833 during excavations by [[St Andrew's Cathedral, St Andrews|St Andrew's Cathedral]], but it was not until 1922 that the surviving components were reunited. The sarcophagus is currently on display at the Cathedral museum in [[St Andrews]], close to the site of its discovery.
==Description== As originally constructed the sarcophagus would have comprised two side panels, two end panels, four corner pieces and a roof slab. The roof slab is entirely missing, as are most of one side and one end panel and a corner piece so that the extant sarcophagus is essentially L-shaped. The external dimensions of the sarcophagus are 177 cm by 90 cm and a height of 70 cm. The stone used is a local sandstone.
The surviving side panel shows, from right to left, a figure breaking the jaws of a lion, a mounted hunter with his sword raised to strike a leaping lion, and hunter on foot, armed with a spear and assisted by a hunting dog, about to attack a wolf. Although it is not certain that the first two figures represent the same person, 19th century illustrations depict them as if they are. The surviving end panel is much simpler, essentially a cross with four small panels between the arms. The fragments of the missing end panel are similar, but not identical, to the surviving one.
==Discovery== The Sarcophagus was discovered within the grounds of The Cathedral near the St Regulus Chapel. The Cathedral had been in use from when it was constructed during the 1100s until it was stripped of all its altars and images, left in ruins and abandoned after 1559 during the Reformation. Much of its remaining stonework was recycled over the years into buildings in the town of [[St Andrews]].<ref name=Buist>{{cite journal|last1=Buist|first1=George|editor1-last=Society of Antiquaries of Scotland|title=On the Ancient Sculptured Monument Discovered at St Andrews, in 1833 [speech given February 27, 1854]|journal=Proceedings of the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland|date=1855|volume=1|pages=234–237|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xyI9AAAAYAAJ&pg=PA234#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=August 27, 2016|publisher=Neill & Company|location=Edinburgh}}</ref>
In the course of digging a grave in 1833, workmen discovered the remaining large fragments of the sarcophagus at a depth of about 6 to 8 feet.<ref name=Buist/> Through the years various casts of the pieces were made <ref name = Buist/><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Foster|first1=Sally|title=Expiscation! Disentangling the later biography of the St Andrews Sarcpohagus|journal=Ancient Lives: Object, People and Place in Early Scotland. Essays for David V Clarke on his 70th birthday|date=2016|pages=165–186|publisher=Sidestone Press|location=Leiden}}</ref>but the original pieces were not reassembled until 1922.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Foster|first1=Sally|title=The St. Andrews Sarcophagus: A Pictish Masterpiece and Its International Connections|date=1998|publisher=Four Courts Press|page=41|url=https://books.google.com/?id=EZFnAAAAMAAJ&dq=editions%3A8YymnXdCVmsC&q=1922|accessdate=August 27, 2016|isbn=9781851824144}}</ref>
==Historical opinion== [[Image:ÓengusmacFergusa.JPG|300px|thumb|right|This is the royal figure on the St Andrew's sarcophagus. The figure is dressed like a late Roman emperor, bearing on the neckline of the garment what is probably a ''kaiserfibel'' like that depicted on [[Justinian]] in the mosaic at [[Basilica of San Vitale|San Vitale]], [[Ravenna]]. This is in the grandest tradition of ''imitatio imperii''. It may therefore be taken as an indirect depiction of the king who commissioned it.<ref>See T. M. Charles Edwards, "'The Continuation of Bede', s.a. 750: high-kings of Tara and 'Bretwaldas'".</ref>]] Historians differ on who was likely to have been interred in the sarcophagus. Although it is generally presumed that it was commissioned by the [[List of kings of the Picts|Pictish King]] [[Óengus I|Óengus, or Onuist]], a Christian who died in 761, whether it was actually used for his corpse,<ref>MacLean, Douglas. "The Northumbrian Perspective" in Simon Taylor (ed.), ''Kings, clerics and chronicles in Scotland, 500–1297: essays in honour of Marjorie Ogilvie Anderson on the occasion of her ninetieth birthday''. Dublin: Four Courts Press, 2000. {{ISBN|1-85182-516-9}} (pp. 200–201)</ref> for his predecessor, [[Nechtan mac Der Ilei]],<ref>Henderson, George & Isabel Henderson, ''The Art of the Picts'', London: Thames and Hudson, 2004. 0-500-23807-3 (pp. 155–156)</ref> or for a later personage<ref>Clancy, Thomas Owen. ''Caustantín son of Fergus (Uurgust)'' in ''The Oxford Companion to Scottish History'', Oxford & New York: Oxford UP, 2002. {{ISBN|0-19-211696-7}}</ref> is unclear.
==Notes== <references/>

(ed.), ''The St Andrews Sarcophagus: A Pictish Masterpiece and its International Connections.'' Dublin: Four Courts Press, 1998. {{ISBN|1-85182-414-6}} * Foster Sally M.(2016) Expiscation! Essays for David V Clarke on his 70th birthday, Leiden: Sidestone Press, pp. 165-186. * Henderson, George & Henderson, Isabel, ''The Art of the Picts: Sculpture and Metalwork in Early Medieval Scotland.'' London: Thames & Hudson, 2004. {{ISBN|0-500-23807-3}} * Smyth, Alfred P. (ed.), ''Seanchas: Studies in Early Medieval Irish Archaeology, History and Literature in Honour of Francis J. Byrne.'' [[File:Sword-Swallower Johnny Fox.jpg|thumb|400px|[[Johnny Fox (performer)|Johnny Fox]] sword swallowing at [[Maryland Renaissance Festival]].]] '''Sword swallowing''' is a skill in which the performer passes a [[sword]] through the mouth and down the esophagus to the [[stomach]]. This feat is not [[swallowing]] in the traditional sense; the natural processes that constitute swallowing do not take place, but are repressed in order to keep the passage from the [[mouth]] to the stomach open for the sword. The practice is dangerous and there is risk of injury or death.
==History== [[File:The great Victorina Troupe.jpg|thumb|alt=circus poster: The great Victorina Troupe|The Great Victorina Troupe: originators and presenters of the most marvelous sword swallowing act on earth|left]] [[File:Sword swallower in 1980.jpg|thumb|left|<Center>Street performer</center>]]
Sword swallowing spread to [[Greece]] and [[Rome]] in the 1st century AD and to [[China]] in the 8th century. In [[Japan]], it became a part of the Japanese acrobatic theatre, [[Sarugaku|Sangaku]], which included [[fire eating]], [[tightrope walking]], [[juggling]] and early [[illusion]]. In [[Europe]] it developed into yet a third distinct type of performance associated with the medieval [[jongleur]]s, that of the [[busking|street performance]].
Sword swallowing was performed during the [[Middle Ages]] as part of [[street theatre]] and was popular at festivals and other large gatherings. It began to die out in the mid-19th century, and was outlawed in Scandinavia in 1893.
According to an early 19th-century English magazine article<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=AvQ0AAAAMAAJ&pg=PA124&lpg=PA124&dq=%22jugglers+in+india,+from+a+late+narrative%22&source=bl&ots=4xvhdvcBFJ&sig=0uXUrVhapNx1Vv3EYtqO2L68QMc&hl=en&sa=X&ei=iCXQUr2TEIWe0QXb3YDgCQ&ved=0CC0Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22jugglers%20in%20india%2C%20from%20a%20late%20narrative%22&f=false] 'Jugglers in India, from a late narrative', quoted in ''Select Reviews and Spirit of Foreign Magazines'', ed. Enos Bronson, Philadelphia, 1810: p.124</ref> the abilities of sword-swallowers in India were considered incredible when first reported in England. In 1813 'swallowing the sword' was advertised as among the new and astonishing feats<ref>'The swallowing of the sword, and the novelty of the other performances, have attracted the attention of the public beyond any thing that has appeared in the metropolis for many years past.' ''The Times''(London, England), 27 July 1813, p.2</ref><ref>'The Indian Jugglers surprised the town by swallowing a sword...' ''The Times'',(London, England), 30 September 1820, p.3</ref> performed by the Indian Jugglers then appearing in London. The troupe was led by the famous juggler and sword swallower Ramo Samee, who continued to perform until his death in London in August 1850, having at times also toured Europe and America.<ref>Article from the ''Salem Gazette'', 5 October 1819</ref> From 1850 to the 1890s a small number of sword swallowers performed in the UK, such as Martha Mitchell (c 1855) and Benedetti (1863–95), and in the US, including Lawson Peck (c 1850s), Ling Look (c 1872), Wandana (died May 9, 1875), and Harry Parsons (died December 1880). The best-known North American sword swallower of this time was Fred McLone, better known to the public as "Chevalier Cliquot", who performed from 1878 to the early 20th century.
In 1893 sword swallowing was featured at the [[World Columbian Exposition]] at the Chicago World's Fair.
In the early 1900s traveling [[circuses]] and [[sideshow]]s featured sword swallowers. In Europe performers tried to swallow large numbers of swords; in America there was a focus on the novel and bizarre.{{clarify|date=September 2013}} Some tried to swallow longer swords, many swords, hot swords, [[bayonet]]s or glowing [[neon sign|neon tubes]]. Sword swallowers appeared on the same bill as magicians such as [[Houdini]]. [[Western Europe]] and [[England]] also saw an increase in sword swallowing interest during this period, with many cross-Atlantic influences. During the late 19th century and early 20th century, traveling magic shows from the Orient toured Europe and America; some included sword swallowing. The middle of the 20th century saw a demise in circuses in general and [[sideshow]]s in particular.
==Anatomy and method== [[Image:Pharynx.gif|thumb|alt=pharynx|The pharynx|201x201px]]The performer must first lean the head back, hyper-extending the neck, and relax the upper esophageal sphincter (a generally involuntary muscle that contracts the top of the esophagus). Retching must be controlled while the sword, lubricated by saliva, is inserted through the mouth and past the pharynx.
Once past the pharynx and sphincter the sword passes swiftly, assisted by gravity, straightening the flexible esophagus. The stomach, at an angle to the esophagus, is brought into line as the sword enters through the cardiac opening.<ref name="SSU">Witcombe, Brian. [http://www.bmj.com/cgi/content/full/331/7524/1080?? "Sword swallowing uncertainties."] ''British Medical Journal.'' 5 Nov 2005. Retrieved 16 Sept. 2009</ref> Some swallowers consume a large meal or drink water before performing to give the stomach a more vertical orientation, allowing for easier passage of the sword.<ref name="SSU"/> Careful focus is required to complete the process without injury, as the sword passes within millimetres of vital body parts such as the aorta, heart and lungs.<ref name="WM"/>
==Physical consequences==
Most serious sword swallowing injuries and fatalities occur after minor injuries or while attempting a feat beyond that of a "normal" sword swallow.<ref name="WM"/> The most common injury is a sore throat when first learning, after frequent consecutive performances, or after swallowing curved swords or several swords at once.<ref name="WM"/> Swallowing multiple swords simultaneously over time can also lead to distension of the esophagus.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/ "Sword Diet Did Not Agree: M'Lone's Exhibition Had Rather Serious Results."] ''New York Times.'' 21 Jan. 1894. Retrieved 29 Sept. 2009</ref> A minor injury may predispose the performer to sustaining a more major one, including perforation of the esophagus, stomach, heart, lungs, and other organs in proximity to the path of the sword, or intestinal bleeding. Twenty-nine deaths have been reported as a result of sword swallowing injuries since 1880.<ref name="WM"/>
===Medical case reports=== * A 59-year-old man experienced chest pain and severe dysphagia following practice for his sword swallowing act. An esophageal perforation was found and surgically repaired; 19 days later a leak at the site required a transhiatal esophagectomy with a left cervical esophagogastrostomy. The patient recovered normally, but ceased the practice of sword swallowing.<ref name="EPSS">Scheinin, Scott A., MD, and Patrick R. Wells, MD. [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC101136/ "Esophageal Perforation in a Sword Swallower."] ''Texas Heart Institute Journal.'' 28(2001): 65-68. {{PMC|101136}}. 17 Sept. 2009</ref> * A 27-year-old woman reported neck pain and a single episode of hematemesis (vomiting blood) after pricking her throat while practicing her sword swallowing act with a sharp dagger. The injury was found to be immediately below the esophageal sphincter, and the patient was admitted to intensive care and placed on intravenous antibiotics and a proton-pump inhibitor. She recovered well and returned to all previous activities with the exception of sword swallowing.<ref>Martin, Matthew MD, Scott Steele, MD, Philip Mullenix, MD, William Long, MD, and Seth Izenberg, MD. "Management of Esophageal Perforation in a Sword Swallower: A Case Report and Review of the Literature." ''The Journal of Trauma, Injury Infection, and Critical Care''. 59.1(2005): 233-235.</ref>
==Contributions to science== [[File:Hans Rosling swallows sword.jpg|thumb|[[Hans Rosling]] of Gapminder Foundation swallows a [[bayonet]] during his [[TED (conference)|TED]] talk]]The abilities of sword-swallowers have proven useful to the progress of medical knowledge, specifically in the development and advancement of upper endoscopy.<ref name="EPSS"/>
In 1868 Adolf Kussmaul of Freiburg, Germany, performed an esophagoscopy on a sword-swallower using a rigid 47 cm tube, mirrors, and a gasoline lamp.<ref name="WM"/> The apparatus, an early endoscope, allowed him to examine the esophagus and the fundus of the stomach.<ref name="EPSS"/>
In 1897 a Scottish physician named Stevens performed digestive experiments with a sword swallower assistant; small metal tubes, pierced with holes and filled with meat, were swallowed and after a time regurgitated, allowing Stevens to examine the extent of the digestion that had taken place.<ref>Hopkins, Albert A. ''Magic, Stage Illusions, and Scientific Diversions, Including Trick Photography''. New York: Munn & Co., Inc., 1911.</ref>
In 1906 a doctor named Cremer performed an electrocardiogram by passing an electrode down the esophagus of a sword swallower.{{citation needed|date=September 2013}} This approach has since been proven useful by numerous studies; esophageal recording at a location in proximity to the heart improves signal detection.<ref>Machler, Heinrich E. et al. [http://www.anesthanalg.com/content/86/1/34.full.pdf+html "A New High-Resolution Esophageal Electrocardiography Recording Technique: An Experimental Approach for the Detection of Myocardial lschemia."] ''Anesthesia & Analgesia.'' 86.1 (1998): 34-39. 21 November 2009</ref>
From 2003 to 2006, a research study on the effects of sword swallowing was conducted by Brian Witcombe, consultant radiologist at the [[Gloucestershire Royal Hospital]] in Gloucester, England, and Dan Meyer. The results were published in the ''[[British Medical Journal]]''.<ref name="WM">Witcombe, Brian and Meyer, Dan. [http://www.bmj.com/content/333/7582/1285.full ' 'Sword swallowing and its side effects.' '] ''British Medical Journal.'' 23 Dec. 2006. Retrieved 16 Sept. 2009</ref>
In January 2006, Dan Meyer worked with physicians and researchers in swallowing disorders at Vanderbilt Stallworth Rehabilitation Center at [[Vanderbilt University Medical Center]] in [[Nashville]], [[Tennessee]] to explore whether the techniques involved in sword swallowing could be used to help patients who suffer from swallowing disorders such as [[dysphagia]] or [[achalasia]].<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.vanderbiltstallworthrehab.com/en/healthcare-professionals/leading-technologies/vitastim-therapy |title=Vanderbilt Stallworth Rehabilitation Center |publisher=Vanderbilt Stallworth Rehabilitation Center |date= |accessdate=2013-01-01}}</ref>
In 2007, [[Dai Andrews]] worked with Dr. Sharon Caplan at [[Johns Hopkins University]] on a study to determine whether sword swallowing could be used to help patients who suffer from [[achalasia]], or those who had suffered severe throat trauma.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://theweek.com/article/index/256861/how-to-swallow-a-sword|title=How to swallow a sword|author=Amy Kraft|publisher=The Week|date=25 February 2014|accessdate=24 March 2014}}</ref>
==Sword swallowers== [[Image:Space Cowboy sword swallowing.JPG|thumb|alt=space cowboy|[[Space Cowboy (performer)|Space Cowboy]] swallowing a sword attached to a metal bar from which weights are suspended]] Modern sword swallowers include [[Johnny Fox (performer)|Johnny Fox]], [[Dai Andrews]], [[Brad Byers]], the [[Space Cowboy (performer)|Space Cowboy]], [[Andy Kaufman]], [[Matt the Knife]], [[Lucky Diamond Rich]], [[Ryan Stock]], [[Josh Routh]], [[Aerial Manx]], [[Alex Magala]], [[David Blaine]], [[Johnny Strange]].
==''Guinness World Records''== In 2009, the [[Guinness World Record]] for longest sword swallowed was achieved by Natasha Veruschka with a 58 cm (22.83 in) long sword.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/longest-sword-swallowed/|title=Longest Sword Swallowed|publisher=Guinness World Records|accessdate=25 March 2014}}</ref>
The Guinness World Record for 'Most swords swallowed underwater' is 4 and was achieved by Chayne Hultgren (a.k.a. [[Space Cowboy (performer)|The Space Cowboy]], Australia) on the set of 'Lo Show dei Record' in Milan, Italy, on 11 July 2014. He was also the first person to swallow a sword underwater on May 9, 2006 at Manly Ocean World Aquarium in Sydney Australia. He performed this under water feat in a tank of live sharks.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/world-records/most-swords-swallowed-underwater|title=Most swords swallowed underwater|publisher=}}</ref>
Chayne Hultgren (a.k.a. The Space Cowboy) also holds the most official 'Guinness World Record' for sword swallowing including 'Most swords swallowed at once' (24 swords), 'Most swords swallowed while juggling' (18 swords), 'Most swords swallowed while riding a unicycle' (3 swords swallowed on a 3m tall unicycle) and 'Longest lightning bolt to strike swallowed sword'. The measured distance the stream of electrical discharge traveled from Australia's largest Tesla Coil, owned and operated by Peter Terren (AKA: Dr Electric), to the handle of Chayne's swallowed sword was 3 feet 10 inches. The sword blade measured 62 cm and was swallowed all the way to the hilt on the 20th of April 2013. Perth, WA, Australia.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9UMclIYkApM|title=Shocking World Record by The Space Cowboy!!! (Electric sword swallow)|first=|last=Chayne Hultgren TheSpaceCowboy|date=26 April 2013|publisher=|via=YouTube}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/news/2012/9/the-space-cowboy-chayne-hultgren-record-holder-profile-video-44570|title=The Space Cowboy: Chayne Hultgren - Record Holder Profile video|date=4 September 2012|publisher=}}</ref> As of July 2016 The Space Cowboy currently holds 44 official [[Guinness World Records]]. He is Australia's most prolific record breaker.
In 2009, the Guinness World Record for "Largest Curve in a Sword Swallowed" was achieved by [[Dai Andrews]] with a 120 degree curved sword.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/records-7000/largest-curve-in-a-sword-swallowed/|title=Largest Curve in a Sword Swallowed|publisher=Guinness World Records|accessdate=25 March 2014}}</ref>
[[Brad Byers]] holds the Guinness World Record for "The Most Swords Swallowed and Twisted at One Time" by swallowing ten 27 inch swords one at a time and then twisting all ten swords 180 degrees in his throat.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/records-11000/most-swords-swallowed-and-twisted/|title=Most Swords Swallowed and Twisted|publisher=Guinness World Records|accessdate=25 March 2014}}</ref>
Thomas Blackthorne made the sword known as "The Sword of Swords". It holds the Guinness World Record for the most swallowed sword and has been swallowed by 40 of the world's most known sword swallowers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/most-swallowed-sword/|title=Most Swallowed Sword|publisher=Guinness World Records|accessdate=25 March 2014}}</ref>

:''[[Thriambus (genus)]] (Fennah, 1964) is a genus of [[Delphacidae]]. [[Culex thriambus]] is a species of the genus [[Culex]].'' {{redirect|Triumphus|the Italian theologian|Augustinus Triumphus}} A '''thriambus''' (also spelled '''thriamb''', '''thriambas''', or '''thriambos'''; [[Ancient Greek|Greek]] {{lang|grc|[[:wikt:θρίαμβος|θρίαμβος]]}}) is a [[hymn]] to [[Dionysus]], sung in processions in his honour, and at the same time an epithet of the god himself, according to [[Diodorus]] (4.5.2):
''Thriambus'' is a name that has been given him, they say, because he was the first of those of whom we have a record to have celebrated a triumph (''thriambos'') upon entering his native land after his campaign, this having been done when he returned from [[Ἰνδία|India]] with great booty.
It was loaned into [[Old Latin]] via [[Etruscan language|Etruscan]] as ''{{lang|la|triumpus}}'', in [[Classical Latin]] taking the form ''{{lang|la|triumphus}}'', the [[Roman triumph]] where the victorious general takes the role of Dionysus as leader of the procession, later associated with {{lang|la|[[Jupiter (mythology)|Iuppiter]]}} rather than Dionysus. [[Arrian]] traces the custom to [[Alexander the Great]] when he states (''[[Anabasis Alexandri|Anabasis]]'' 6b.28):
Certain authors have said (though to me the statement seems incredible) that Alexander led his forces through [[Carmania (satrapy)|Carmania]] lying extended with his Companions upon two covered waggons joined together, the flute being played to him; and that the soldiers followed him wearing garlands and sporting. Food was provided for them, as well as all kinds of dainties which had been brought together along the roads by the Carmanians. They say that he did this in imitation of the Bacchic revelry of Dionysus, because a story was told about that deity, that after subduing the Indians he traversed the greater part of Asia in this manner and received the appellation of ''Thriambus'', and that for the same reason the processions in honour of victories after war were called ''thriambi''.
The term's etymology is connected with the word {{lang|grc|θρῖον}} "fig leaf" by [[Aemilius Luetcke]] (1829) who refers to the epithet {{lang|grc|Συκίτης}} "of the [[fig tree]]" of Dionysus. An old hypothesis is that the word is borrowed from [[Phrygian language|Phrygian]] or [[Pelasgian language|Pelasgian]], and literally means "Dreischritt", i. e., "three-step", compare ''[[Iamb (poetry)|iamb]]'' and ''[[dithyramb]]'', but H. S. Versnel rejects this etymology and suggests instead a derivation from a cultic exclamation.{{cite book|last=Versnel|first=H. S.|title=Triumphus: An Inquiry Into the Origin, Development and Meaning of the Roman Triumph|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pPjBSq2jCrcC&pg=PA16|accessdate=2 January 2015|year=1970|publisher=Brill Publishers|location=Leiden, Netherlands|isbn=90-04-02325-9|pages=16–38|chapter=I. 2 Θρίαμβος}} From the time of [[Roman Greece]] (2nd century BC), the Greek term increasingly narrows to a translation of Latin ''[[:wikt:triumphus|triumphus]]''. In [[Modern Greek]], {{lang|el|θρίαμβος}} is used in the same generalized meaning as English ''[[:wikt:en:triumph|triumph]]''. ==Notes== {{Reflist}} ==References== *Janda, Michael: ''Elysion: Entstehung und Entwicklung der griechischen Religion'' (2005). *Luetcke, Aemilius, ''De Graecorum dithyrambis et poetis dithyrambicis'', Berlin (1829). *{{cite book|last=Versnel|first=H. S.|title=Triumphus: An Inquiry Into the Origin, Development and Meaning of the Roman Triumph|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pPjBSq2jCrcC&pg=PA16|accessdate=2 January 2015|year=1970|publisher=Brill Publishers|location=Leiden, Netherlands|isbn=90-04-02325-9|pages=16–38|chapter=I. 2 Θρίαμβος}} ==See also== *[[Dithyramb]] *[[Iamb (foot)|Iamb]] *[[Bacchanalia]] *[[Roman triumph]] [[Category:Epithets of Dionysus]] [[Category:Hymns to Dionysus]] [[Category:Religious music]] [[Category:Victory]] [[Category:Etymologies]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Alexander the Great]]

{{Infobox artist | bgcolour = #6495ED | name = Timur Novikov | image = Timur_246b.jpg | imagesize = | caption = Novikov in 2000 | birth_name = Timur Petrovich Novikov | birth_date = {{birth-date||dt=1958}} | birth_place = [[St. Petersburg|Leningrad]], [[Russia]] | death_date = {{death-date||dt=2002}} | death_place = [[Leningrad|St. Petersburg]], [[Russia]] | nationality = {{flagicon|Russia}} [[Russia]]n | field = [[Painting]], [[Graphic art|Graphic Art]], [[Design]], [[Film director|Film]], [[Art theory|Art Theory]], [[Philosophy]], [[Textiles]] | training = Art Club, House of Pioneers, Leningrad; Young Art Historians Club, Leningrad; Institut des Arts Plastiques de Paris, France | movement = [[Soviet Nonconformist Art#The Petersburg group|Nonconformist Art]] | works = | patrons = | influenced by = [[Mikhail Larionov]], [[John Cage]], [[Robert Rauschenberg]], [[Andy Warhol]], [[Daniel Burin]] | influenced = | founded = Novye khudozhniki (New Artists); Novye kompozitory (New Composers); New Academy of Fine Arts | awards = [[Nika Award]] (Design), 1987 }}
'''Timur Petrovich Novikov''' (September 24, 1958, [[Leningrad]] – May 23, 2002, [[St. Petersburg]]) was a [[Russia]]n [[philosopher]], [[Drawing|graphic artist]], [[designer]], [[Painting|painter]], [[Art theory|art theorist]] and [[curator]]. He is considered one of the most influential proponents of [[Soviet Nonconformist Art#The Petersburg group|Nonconformist Art]] before and after [[revolutions of 1989|the fall of the Iron Curtain]] in Russia.
==Life and work==
As he grew up in the [[Soviet Union]], Novikov experienced its cultural and political constraints. His artistic education began at the age of seven at the House of Pioneers in Leningrad, and later at the Young Art Historians Club at the [[Russian Museum]] in the same city.
In 1977 he became a member of the Letopis (Chronicles) art group; and in 1982 he founded the Novye khudozhniki (New Artists) movement. During the 1980s Novikov worked at the Russian Museum and enjoyed access to its collection and archive, as well as close working relationships with its curators. This connection lasted to when he started work as an artist. In 1990 and 1991 he studied as an intern at the Institut des Arts Plastiques (Institute of Plastic Arts) in [[Paris]], France.
During the 1980s and 1990s Novikov was a regular participant in the Pop Mekhanika show of experimental composer [[Sergey Kuryokhin]] and worked on its stage design. Several pop groups from the show worked with him to explore a new visual and stage design. In 1983 Novikov founded and led an experimental rock-group Novye Kompozitory (New Composers) and invented new musical instruments for it. He was also involved in a number of film projects as an actor and artist, and made a name as an innovative film designer. In 1987 Novikov shared the [[Nika Award]] for his contribution to the popular Russian film [[Assa (film)|Assa]], directed by [[Sergei Solovyov]].
The New Academy of Fine Arts, founded by Novikov in 1989, soon became a well-known meeting point for the Leningrad, Russian and international art scene and a symbol for the spirit of freedom and recomposition in the new Russia. The academy and artist community, named also after its address Pushkinskaya 10, was at first self-organized by artists. It later offered ateliers as well as regular courses for students, including scholarships. The academy, with Novikov as one of its most prominent teachers, was sometimes referred to as an underground art project, but also cooperated with established art institutions, among them the [[Russian Museum]] and the [[Hermitage Museum]].
The core conception of the academy was called Neo-Academism and comprised a specific teacher-student relationship as well as a focus on the historic and aesthetic perspective of [[Neoclassicism]].
Novikov also contributed to numerous art exhibitions outside Russia. His style of painting combined a bold avant-garde attitude with refined classically based conceptions of Neo-Academism. Furthermore, he contributed to contemporary [[art theory]], writing books such as "The New Russian Classicism" (1998), "Horizons" (2000), and "Intercontacts" (2000), published by the [[Russian Museum]].
A lengthy illness led to blindness in the later part of Novikov's career. He continued working as a lecturer at the New Academy and led assistants to work on graphic works. Novikov died of pneumonia on May 23, 2002, in St. Petersburg.
Posthumous exhibitions of Novikov's works were held at the Moscow Russian Museum and in Brussels in 2002, in Denmark 2004, London 2005 and 2012, and several times in St. Petersburg.<ref>[http://www.timurnovikov.ru/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=85&Itemid=23&lang=en timurnovikov.ru: Personal exhibitions], registered Dec 3, 2014</ref> In spring 2013 the Moscow Museum of Modern Art presented a large-scale solo retrospective of Novikov's work, curated by Ekaterina Andreeva, the leading academic researcher at the State Russian Museum and author of Novikov's biography.<ref>[http://www.mmoma.ru/en/exhibitions/gogolevsky/timur/ mmoma.ru: Timur], registered Dec 3, 2014</ref>
'''Collaboration'''
In 2015, the estate of Timur Novikov collaborated with Russian street wear designer Gosha Rubchinskiy. The resulting collection consisted of T-shirts, sweatshirts and caps incorporating designs from Novikov's work. The 'eternal sun' motif is the stand out design element and has previously been appropriated by Rubchinskiy, who greatly reveres his art. The pieces were very well received, selling out within minutes on the Dover Street Market e-shop.
==Collections==
*State Tretyakov Gallery (Moscow, Russia) *Shchusev State Museum of Architecture (Moscow, Russia) *Tsaritsyno State Historical, Architectural, Art and Landscape Museum (Moscow, Russia) *State Russian Museum (St. Petersburg, Russia) *Museum of New Academy of Fine Arts (St. Petersburg, Russia) *Museum of History of St. Petersburg (St. Petersburg, Russia) *Museum of Political History of Russia (St. Petersburg, Russia) *Kaliningrad State Art Gallery (Kaliningrad, Russia) *Orel Museum of Fine Arts (Orel, Russia) *Ryazan State Regional Art Museum (Ryazan, Russia) *Tver Regional Picture Gallery (Tver, Russia) *Simferopol Art Museum (Simferopol, Crimea) *Art Museum of Estonian (Tallinn, Estonia) *Museum of History and Contemporary Art, Turku, Finland *Stedelijk Museum (Amsterdam, Holland) *Centre Georges Pompidou (Paris, France) *Tate Modern (London, England) *Victoria and Albert Museum (London, England)) *Schwules Museum (Berlin, Germany) *Museum of Modern Art (Vienna, Austria) *Frederick R. Weisman Museum of Art (Los Angeles, California, USA) *Zimmerli Art Museum, Rutgers University (New Brunswick, New Jersey, USA)

[[File:Avenida Bolivar of Managua.jpg|thumb|Trees of Life illuminated at night on [[Avenida Bolívar]], Managua, 2016]] The '''Trees of Life''' (Spanish: Árboles de la Vida) are a public art installation in [[Managua]], [[Nicaragua]]. Begun in 2013 to honor the 34th anniversary of the [[Nicaraguan Revolution|Sandinista Revolution]],<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://hyperallergic.com/117612/psychedelic-symbols-of-state-power-in-nicaragua/|title=Psychedelic Symbols of State Power in Nicaragua|last=Mallonee|first=Laura C.|date=2014-03-31|work=Hyperallergic|access-date=2018-05-11|language=en-US}}</ref> the Trees of Life are a city beautification project of First Lady [[Rosario Murillo]], who has also served as Nicaragua's Vice President since 2017.
[[File:Artificial flowers on the streets of the city.jpg|thumb|left|Trees of Life in daylight, Managua, 2017]] The approximately 140 abstract, brightly colored tree sculptures were reportedly inspired by the 1909 work by Austrian painter [[Gustav Klimt]] called [[The Tree of Life, Stoclet Frieze|The Tree of Life]].<ref name=":0" /> They are made of metal and decorated 2.5 million tiny light bulbs in total.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Rogers|first1=Tim|title=Nicaragua's capital city is batshit crazy, which is why I love it|url=https://splinternews.com/nicaraguas-capital-city-is-batshit-crazy-which-is-why-1793853419|accessdate=10 May 2018|work=Splinter|date=December 8, 2015}}</ref> Standing 42 to 56 feet tall, they cost a reported $20,000<ref>{{cite news|last1=Wilkinson|first1=Tracy|title=Nicaragua's first lady is a powerful partner of president|url=http://www.latimes.com/world/mexico-americas/la-fg-nicaragua-trees-20150524-story.html|accessdate=10 May 2018|work=Los Angeles Times|date=May 24, 2015}}</ref> to $25,000 ([[United States dollar|USD]]) a piece and in total $1 million to light annually.<ref>{{cite news|title=The violent end of Daniel Ortega’s decade of quiet|url=https://www.economist.com/news/americas/21741216-without-venezuelan-aid-president-can-no-longer-buy-support-potential-adversaries|accessdate=10 May 2018|work=The Economist|date=April 26, 2018|language=en}}</ref>
The Trees often line streets and parks in Managua and sometimes accompany other statues, including the illuminated statue of [[Hugo Chávez]] in Managua's [[Hugo Chávez Roundabout]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.laprensa.com.ni/2016/07/28/nacionales/2074520-rotonda-hugo-chavez-es-la-mimada-en-managua|title=Rotonda Hugo Chávez es la “mimada” en Managua|last=Moncada|first=Roy|date=2016-07-28|work=La Prensa|access-date=2018-05-12|language=es-ES}}</ref> which cost $1.1 million to construct, and the statue of Nicaraguan revolutionary (and Murillo's great-uncle) [[Augusto Sandino]] on the stage of Managua's outdoor concert venue, the [[Acoustic Shell]].<ref name=":0" />
Commentary on the visual style of the installation has been mixed. One observer compared them to the lavish [[Catholic Church|Catholic]] cathedrals constructed in the colonial period, saying "these vibrant public artworks have drastically brightened the streets of Managua — and in a relatively short time."<ref name=":0" /> However other viewers have called them "garish".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/04/26/opinion/daniel-ortega-nicaragua.html|title=Opinion {{!}} The Beginning of the End for Ortega?|last=Jarquín Chamorro|first=Mateo|date=2018-04-26|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-05-12|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref><ref name=":1" />
In the [[2018 Nicaraguan protests|2018 protests]], demonstrators toppled, and in some cases set on fire,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Galeano|first1=Luis Manuel|title=2 more killed in Nicaragua social security protests: reports|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/nicaragua-is-open-to-negotiations-over-social-security-in-wake-of-deadly-protests/2018/04/21/155cb298-4573-11e8-ad8f-27a8c409298b_story.html?noredirect=on|accessdate=11 May 2018|work=Washington Post|date=21 April 2018}}</ref> a number of the Trees, a gesture widely interpreted as a rebuke to the administration and Murillo specifically.<ref name=":1">{{cite news|last1=Phillips|first1=Tom|title=Nicaragua's toppling 'trees' strike ominous note for Daniel Ortega's rule|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/apr/28/nicaragua-daniel-ortega-trees-of-life-protests|accessdate=11 May 2018|work=The Guardian|date=28 April 2018|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2018/04/22/604762080/violent-unrest-continues-in-nicaragua-over-social-security-reforms|title=Nicaragua's President Withdraws Social Security Reforms That Sparked Violent Unrest|last=Diao|first=Alexis|date=April 22, 2018|work=NPR.org|access-date=2018-05-11|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/nicaragua-protesters-clash-with-police-1524368041|title=Nicaragua Protesters Clash With Police|last=Córdoba|first=José de|date=2018-04-22|work=Wall Street Journal|access-date=2018-05-11|language=en-US|issn=0099-9660}}</ref>

The '''World Soundtrack Academy''' ('''WSA''', or '''World Soundtrack Awards'''), launched in 2001 by the [[Film Fest Gent]], is aimed at organizing and overseeing the educational, cultural and professional aspects of the art of [[film music]], including the preservation of the history of the soundtrack and its worldwide promotion. The event takes place yearly in [[Ghent]], [[Belgium]] with the ceremony usually at the Capitole Concert Hall. Usually, the [[Brussels Philharmonic]] conducted by maestro [[Dirk Brossé]] performs the awarded music at the ceremony.
==Main Awards== The '''three main categories''' are: *[[World Soundtrack Award for Soundtrack Composer of the Year|Soundtrack Composer of the Year]] *[[World Soundtrack Award for Best Original Soundtrack of the Year|Best Original Score of the Year]] *[[World Soundtrack Award for Best Original Song Written Directly for a Film|Best Original Song Written Directly for a Film]]
==Other awards== *[[World Soundtrack Award for Discovery of the Year|Discovery of the Year]] *[[World Soundtrack Award - Public Choice|Public Choice Award]] (2001–2002, 2004–) *[[World Soundtrack Award - Lifetime Achievement|Lifetime Achievement Award]] *[[World Soundtrack Award - Best Young Belgian Composer|Best Young Belgian Composer]] *[[World Soundtrack Award for Major Contribution to the Art of Film Music and Sound|Major Contribution to the Art of Film Music and Sound]] (handed out occasionally) *[[World Soundtrack Award for Most Creative Use of Existing Material on a Soundtrack|Most Creative Use of Existing Material on a Soundtrack]] (2001) *[[World Soundtrack Award for Best Original Score of the Year Not Released on an Album|Best Original Score of the Year Not Released on an Album]] (2001)
==Background== [[Brussels Philharmonic]] conducted by maestro [[Dirk Brossé]] performs fragments from several scores during the awards ceremony at the [[Kuipke]] in Ghent. Usually, the winner of the WSAward of Composer of the Year is invited to the ceremony's next edition to perform a concert with his music.
Seminars for and with film music professionals, colloquia and concerts are also being organized next to the gala evening. There are also CD releases (with live concerts by [[Hans Zimmer]], [[George Fenton]] and [[Georges Delerue]]) and the book ''Moving Music'' (by Lannoo - Tielt) that was published in 2005, in response to 20 years of film music at the film festival. In 2007, the CD series ''For the Record'' was launched, to shed light on the works of composers who had already performed at the festival. Hitherto, this series is made up of CDs by [[Craig Armstrong (composer)|Craig Armstrong]] (2007), [[Mychael Danna]] (2008), [[Angelo Badalamenti]] (2009), [[Shigeru Umebayashi]] (2010), [[Gabriel Yared]] (2011) and [[Cliff Martinez]] (2014).
The festival is praised as one of the first cultural organizations to turn the spotlight on film music, which gave it the status of a pioneer. It has built up a strong reputation by organizing concerts, such as the very first concert of music by [[Hans Zimmer]].
